paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy combination cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Multiple murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched controls including vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle treatments across repeat experiments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
